lettertext.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

26 A
p
1592
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The States l
re
to hir
Ma
tie
,
towchinge their trade w
th
e Enemy.
L. Willowghbies
demaundes.
The
merchantes adventurers
cawse.

page.lettertext:
fol.271r
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere inclosed is
a letter from
e states unto her Ma
tie
whiche is
their answear to a mater proposed long a goe, but
by reason of their Recesse, and pretense of many
lettes, not resolved on till nowe. It concerneth
their Commerce and trade w
t
e Enemie, w
ch
is de-
fended w
t
suche reasons, as their letter doth alleage:
but they tell me more in privat,
at it is not possi-
ble for them, to drawe this people to better termes.
Were
e mater of
at q
a
litie, as to sette an other
course, might depend altogether upon their resolu-
tion,
at sitte for
e states, there might be hope of
some redresse to her Hig
nes
contentac
o
n. For I see
there are divers,
at would willingly doe somwhat,
to reforme those abuses. But in thinges apperte-
ning to
e trafficke of
e contrey, they are tied to
suche instructions, as
e marchants list to give,
from w
ch
they may not varie, w
t
out special com-
mission. I have laboured very ear-
nestly, to gette a favorable answear to
e suite of
my L. Willughby: but though they speake a litle
fairer, then they have done heeretofore, they con-
clude upon nothing for my L. satisfaction. Be-
cause they write their owne excuses, in a letter to
her Ma
tie
I will not trouble yo
r
L. with an
other rehersall. They have sent their letter to be
delivered, by their Agent
M
r
Caron
, for
at I thinke
he hath somw
at
to say by worde of mouth.
By moving them often in
e Marchants affaires, I
have so muche obtened, as nowe they have resolved,
to putte it to Committies, to be chosen on bothe sides,
who, I trust, will make an ende, by some mutual
relenting. But where
e Marchants doe desire a
sur s eance of their Placcart, and a libertie of trafficke
fol.271v
to that they will not yelde: for
at they say
e
Committies, if they list to be tractable, may com-
pound any mater w
t
in two or three meetinges.
I have written this at large to
e company of
e
Marchants residing at
Middelbourgh.
And so I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage. A
p
26
1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
I have sent my L. Willughby,
by this bearer a transcript of
at letter w
ch
e states have
sent to M
r
Caron, to be delivered
to her Ma
tie
.
There is brought unto me nowe, at
e closing
of this letter, and this bearers departure, her
Ma
ties
letter to
e states, and an other to
Count Mau-
rice
, w
t
one from yo
r
L. to my self, bearing date
e 17 of this p
nt
. I will send
e Answear of
e
states, assoone as I receave it. But yo
r
L. will con-
jecture howe soone it may be gotten, considering
at
e letters doe require further succo
rs
to be sent into
France,
and were written by her Ma
tie
when
e
King
was distressed: wheras nowe
e occurrence goeth,
at he hath streitned
e Enemie. For w
ch
I doe as-
sure my self,
at till
ei heare howe
e Kinge hath
spedde in
at encounter, w
ch
they are persuaded is
presently towardes, they will answear to nothing.
